content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it was fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It could be funny and pretty solvable for a clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very simple looking problem but the solution is complex. Was very fun to write a solution

I am doubting whether to also include the string {{point}}, and open the door to floats. I.e.: input could also be {{two hundred two ten five point one five}} for 225.15 (with as rule that after the decimal point, all numbers are simply spelled one by one, without use of ten or hundred).

And, another thing: I think this one is also possible in Reverse mode (which is what I want), but possibly I need to add more tests to show the reverse-players the fact that there are either one-string, or three-string or five-string inputs for 0-9, 10-99 or 100-999. In other words, my question: is it clear enough for Reverse as it is, or shall I add some Test cases?

Yeah adding decimal place won't increase the difficulty by a lot for reverse players.

For the clash, I'm not really sure what do you mean by it. Would be better if you elaborate or even better, a WIP clash.

ty
Thanks for thinking along! I have rephrased the second paragraph of my comment -- I simply wanted to ask whether others think I should add test cases to make it more clear for Reverse players.

Ah I see. For me, I understood the objective by only reading testcase (cuz I'm not a fan of long statement). Of course, it would be better with more testcase but if it's in terms of clearness I think its pretty good already.
Also your solution fails on "nine hundred" I'm not sure is it intentional since it's not a part of testcase.

In the current rules, 900 would be written as 'nine hundred zero ten zero' (see in the goal text also 100 which is 'one hundred one ten zero') -- I simply chose for always five strings for numbers 100-999.

Adding the possibilities of simply 'nine hundred', as well as 'hundred' and 'ten', would make it nicer - and more complex. I intent instead to add the float option to add a small bit of complexity.
Ah okay. But with this logic isn't "two hundred four" should be "two hundred zero ten four"?

Howw that is a very good point, sharp.

I've rephrased the assignment to the higher complexity --> no 'zero'. So, 10 is 'one ten', 200 is 'two hundred', and 204 is 'two hundred four'. And, 900 is now in my solution also possible with 'nine hundred'. This means that 10-99 can be either two or three strings, and 100-999 can be either two, three, four or five strings.
